In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The constructive interference of that protected (\u201cbound\u201d) subspace yields a higher heralding (absorption) probability than a standard partial Bell\u2010measurement distillation.\n 2) Teleportation of a bound\u2010state\u2013encoded qubit: encode a logical qubit into the symmetric two\u2010photon subspace, then teleport it via a central four\u2010mode symmetry\u2010protected Bell analyzer, comparing heralding efficiency to dual\u2010rail teleportation.\n 3) A repeater chain of bound\u2010state\u2010filtered swapping: sequentially fuse multiple Bell pairs with symmetry\u2010protected filters to extend entanglement over many nodes with boosted heralding at each link.\n\nStep 2: Novelty & Pytheus feasibility:\n 1) Option 1 is fully new\u2014no existing Pytheus example uses a bound\u2010state filter as a distillation primitive. This mesh hosts a symmetry-protected two-photon \u201cedge bound state\u201d localized at one boundary port. When two photons arrive simultaneously in the bulk, they preferentially occupy that bound mode via constructive interference\u2014an effective \u201cenhanced absorption.\u201d Two number-resolving detectors monitoring the boundary mode herald (a) successful entanglement swapping between modes 0 and 3 and (b) an elevated heralding probability compared to a conventional two-port Bell-analyzer. Pytheus can optimize a linear\u2010optical multiport plus ancillas to implement the dark bound\u2010state mode. \n 2) Option (2) reduces to a teleportation variant with an encoding twist. \n 3) Option (3) is interesting but may exceed resource limits on a first design.\n\nStep 3: Pick option (1).\n\nStep 4: Novelty: This experiment embeds a Fano\u2010resonance\u2013style bound state (a two\u2010photon \u201cdark\u201d eigenmode in a multiport) into the core measurement of an entanglement\u2010swap. Constructive two\u2010photon interference into that bound mode yields an elevated heralding probability (\u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d), a mechanism not captured by any standard Bell\u2010analyzer or symmetric\u2010subspace projector in existing Pytheus experiments.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility: It uses only SPDC pair sources, linear optics (beam splitters, phase shifters forming a multiport), and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s design space. Alice holds mode 0, Bob holds mode 3. At Charlie\u2019s station, modes 1 and 2 are mixed with two ancillary vacuum modes (4,5) in a Pytheus\u2010designed linear\u2010optical multiport engineered to host a Fano\u2010resonance\u2013style bound state: a symmetry\u2010protected two\u2010photon eigenmode embedded in the continuum of four-port network. When two photons enter the multiport, they preferentially occupy that bound mode and emerge at two heralding detectors monitoring the bound\u2010state outputs. A click pattern on detectors 4 and 5 both (a) implements entanglement swapping\u2014leaving modes 0 and 3 in a Bell state\u2014and (b) exhibits an elevated heralding probability (\u201cenhanced absorption\u201d) compared to a conventional two\u2010port Bell analyzer.     "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Experiment Title: Symmetry-Protected Bound\u2010State Qubit Teleportation with Enhanced Heralding\n\nDescription:\nWe encode a logical qubit into two photonic modes at Alice and Bob by restricting to the symmetric two\u2010photon subspace (\u201cbound state\u201d protected by mode\u2010exchange symmetry), which enhances the coupling (absorption) into detectors. We then teleport this bound\u2010state\u2013encoded qubit from Alice to Bob via a central node Charlie using entanglement swapping. By comparing the heralding statistics to a standard teleporter, we directly observe \u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d due to the symmetry\u2010protected bound\u2010state encoding. The network can be generalized to longer chains or higher\u2010dimensional bound\u2010state encodings.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2022 Alice\u2019s logical qubit: two modes A\u2081, A\u2082, with unknown state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 in the symmetric subspace Span{\u222301\u27e9+\u222310\u27e9, \u222300\u27e9, \u222311\u27e9\u2026 restricted to two\u2010dim logical basis}.  \n\u2022 Two SPDC sources produce Bell\u2010pairs: one between modes B\u2081\u2013C\u2081, one between modes B\u2082\u2013C\u2082. Modes C\u2081,C\u2082 are sent to Charlie; modes B\u2081,B\u2082 go to Bob.  \n\u2022 At Alice: her bound\u2010state qubit in A\u2081,A\u2082 plus the two\u2010mode halves of an entangled resource with Charlie (another SPDC) feed into a linear\u2010optical network.  \n\u2022 Charlie performs a joint, symmetry\u2010respecting four\u2013mode Bell measurement on A\u2081,A\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082 (heralding detectors).  \n\u2022 Upon a specific click pattern, the bound\u2010state qubit is teleported to Bob\u2019s modes B\u2081,B\u2082, still within the symmetric subspace.  \n\u2022 We record both teleportation fidelity and heralding rate\u2014enhanced absorption manifests as higher post\u2010selected rates for bound\u2010state encoding vs. standard dual\u2010rail encoding.\n\nKey Pytheus Config Elements (to be found by Expert):\n\u2022 num_anc = detectors at Charlie  \n\u2022 single_emitters or pair_sources for each SPDC link  \n\u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct ties from Alice to Bob  \n\u2022 target_quantum = logical mapping {\u2223bound0\u27e9\u2192\u2223bound0\u27e9, \u2223bound1\u27e9\u2192\u2223bound1\u27e9}  \n\u2022 loss_func = maximize heralding probability subject to teleportation fidelity\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Use qutrit bound\u2010state encoding (three\u2010mode symmetric subspace) for three\u2010level logic  \n\u2022 Chain multiple teleporter nodes to build a repeater network with symmetry\u2010protected links  \n\u2022 Swap standard swapping nodes for bound\u2010state superdense\u2010coding modules to transmit more information per herald click\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While teleporting a two-photon \u201cbound\u2010state\u201d logical qubit via swapping and comparing heralding rates is an interesting twist on dual\u2010rail teleportation, it does not introduce a genuinely new measurement\u2010induced transformation or network primitive beyond existing entanglement\u2010swapping/teleportation variants. Encoding in the symmetric two\u2010photon subspace is essentially a straightforward extension of multi\u2010mode teleportation, and the claimed \u201cenhanced absorption\u201d lacks a clear mechanism that distinguishes it from simply having two photons available for heralding. This remains an incremental performance comparison rather than a fundamentally novel target (e.g., no new nontrivial bound\u2010state physics or topological protection is demonstrated).  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The proposal must go beyond re\u2010encoding a qubit in two photons and running a standard swap\u2010based teleporter. To be PRL\u2010worthy, you would need to identify a truly new bound\u2010state phenomenon\u2014such as a nonperturbative photon\u2010photon bound state in a nonlinear waveguide or a symmetry\u2010protected topological bound mode\u2014and show how teleportation or network operations uniquely probe that physics. Provide a clear, nontrivial effect that has not been captured by existing teleportation or entanglement\u2010swapping experiments.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Experiment Title: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Qubit Teleportation\n\nexplanation:\n  We encode a logical qubit into two photonic modes (Alice\u2019s modes A\u2080,A\u2081) by restricting to their symmetric subspace (\u201cbound state,\u201d protected by mode-exchange symmetry). A standard Bell-pair source creates an entangled resource between Charlie\u2019s modes C\u2080,C\u2081 and Bob\u2019s modes B\u2080,B\u2081. Alice and Charlie perform a joint four-mode Bell measurement that respects the same symmetry, heralding teleportation of the bound-state qubit from A\u2080,A\u2081 to B\u2080,B\u2081. By comparing the heralding probability and teleportation fidelity of this bound-state scheme to a reference dual-rail teleportation, one directly observes \u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d (higher post-selection rates) due to the symmetry-protected bound state. The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). This interferometer has one special two-photon eigenmode\u2014a \u201cbound state\u201d\u2014protected by its three-fold rotational symmetry.     "output": "Experiment Title: Butterfly\u2010Network Teleportation via a Symmetry\u2010Protected Bound\u2010State Router\n\nexplanation:\n  We propose a four\u2010party \u201cbutterfly\u201d quantum\u2010network coding protocol that simultaneously teleports two unknown qubits across a single central node using one joint measurement. Two SPDC sources at Senders S\u2081 and S\u2082 create Bell pairs on modes (0\u20131) and (2\u20133). S\u2081 retains mode 0 (its unknown qubit), S\u2082 retains mode 2. They send modes 1 and 3 into a four\u2010mode linear\u2010optical \u201cbound\u2010state router\u201d at Relay R. That router is a Pytheus\u2010optimized interferometer (beam splitters + phase shifters) engineered to support a symmetry\u2010protected two\u2010photon bound eigenmode (in analogy to a Fano\u2010type dark state). When both photons occupy this bound subspace, they exit into two heralding detectors (modes 1,3) with anomalously high probability (\u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d). A successful two-click event both (a) projects modes 0\u21925 and 2\u21924 into two cross\u2010linked Bell pairs\u2014i.e. teleporting S\u2081\u2192Receiver 2 (mode 5) and S\u2082\u2192Receiver 1 (mode 4)\u2014and (b) exhibits a higher heralding rate than a conventional two\u2010port Bell\u2010analyzer. The protocol thus implements instantaneous two-way teleportation (network coding) in one bound\u2010state measurement.  \n\n  By comparing the post-selected fidelity and heralding probability of this bound\u2010state router against a standard linear-optical swap, one directly quantifies the absorption enhancement due to the symmetry-protected bound eigenmode. This idea generalizes to higher\u2010dimensional bound states (qutrit router), larger butterfly networks, or repeater chains with sequential bound\u2010state routers.\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Butterfly network coding: simultaneous two-way teleportation via a symmetry-protected bound-state router\",\n  foldername: \"ButterflyBoundRouter\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,                       # two herald detectors at R\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: False,\n  safe_hist: True,\n  samples: 20,\n  target_quantum: [\n    \"0000\",  # |A0 A2 R2 R1> = |00 00> + |01 10> + |10 01> + |11 11>\n    \"0110\",\n    \"1001\",\n    \"1111\"\n  ],\n  in_nodes: [0,2],                  # S\u2081\u2019s and S\u2082\u2019s retained qubits\n  out_nodes: [5,4],                 # Receiver 2 (mode 5) and Receiver 1 (mode 4)\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  heralding_out: [1,3],             # R\u2019s detectors on modes 1 & 3\n  single_emitters: [],              # uses two SPDC pair sources only\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],  \n                                     # forbid any source except (0\u20131) and (2\u20133)\n  number_resolving: True,\n  anc_detectors: [1,3]\n}\n\nExplanation of config fields:\n \u2022 SPDC sources emit into (0\u20131) and (2\u20133).  \n \u2022 Modes 1 & 3 plus two vacuum ancillas enter the Pytheus\u2010designed multiport at R, which implements the symmetry-protected two-photon bound eigenmode.  \n \u2022 Heralding detectors on modes 1 & 3 click together only when the two photons occupy that bound mode, boosting the absorption probability.  \n \u2022 Post-selection yields the target mapping: the retained qubit on mode 0 is teleported to mode 5 (Receiver 2), and qubit on mode 2 to mode 4 (Receiver 1), achieving two simultaneous cross-teleportations in one measurement.  \n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2022 Replace the C\u2082 symmetry bound state with C\u2083 or higher for qutrit network coding.  \n \u2022 Chain multiple bound\u2010state routers for multi-link repeaters with cumulative absorption enhancement.  \n\nThis protocol is a genuine quantum\u2010network coding primitive\u2014not just a standard swap\u2014because a single joint bound\u2010state measurement accomplishes two-way teleportation over a butterfly topology. By demonstrating an \u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d tied to a symmetry\u2010protected bound eigenmode, it opens a new domain of photonic quantum networks where symmetry\u2010induced interference powerfully boosts multi-party transformations."
}

The bound\u2010state structure yields higher cumulative absorption (herald rates) and is robust against photon loss. \n    3) Superdense coding with bound-state qudits: symmetrically encode two classical bits into a two-photon bound state; distribute half the bound-state to Bob via an entanglement\u2010swapping network. Bob decodes by a symmetry-protected measurement that benefits from enhanced absorption cross section.\n\n  Step 2: Novelty and Pytheus obstacles:\n    1) Bound\u2010state-qubit teleportation is not in the explored list; it\u2019s a transformation (teleportation) rather than pure state generation. We then teleport this bound\u2010state\u2013encoded qubit from Alice to Bob via a central node Charlie using entanglement swapping. By comparing the heralding statistics to a standard teleporter, we directly observe \u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d due to the symmetry\u2010protected bound\u2010state encoding. The network can be generalized to longer chains or higher\u2010dimensional bound\u2010state encodings.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2022 Alice\u2019s logical qubit: two modes A\u2081, A\u2082, with unknown state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 in the symmetric subspace Span{\u222301\u27e9+\u222310\u27e9, \u222300\u27e9, \u222311\u27e9\u2026 restricted to two\u2010dim logical basis}.  \n\u2022 Two SPDC sources produce Bell\u2010pairs: one between modes B\u2081\u2013C\u2081, one between modes B\u2082\u2013C\u2082. Modes C\u2081,C\u2082 are sent to Charlie; modes B\u2081,B\u2082 go to Bob.  \n\u2022 At Alice: her bound\u2010state qubit in A\u2081,A\u2082 plus the two\u2010mode halves of an entangled resource with Charlie (another SPDC) feed into a linear\u2010optical network.  \n\u2022 Charlie performs a joint, symmetry\u2010respecting four\u2013mode Bell measurement on A\u2081,A\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082 (heralding detectors).  \n\u2022 Upon a specific click pattern, the bound\u2010state qubit is teleported to Bob\u2019s modes B\u2081,B\u2082, still within the symmetric subspace.  \n\u2022 We record both teleportation fidelity and heralding rate\u2014enhanced absorption manifests as higher post\u2010selected rates for bound\u2010state encoding vs. standard dual\u2010rail encoding.\n\nKey Pytheus Config Elements (to be found by Expert):\n\u2022 num_anc = detectors at Charlie  \n\u2022 single_emitters or pair_sources for each SPDC link  \n\u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct ties from Alice to Bob  \n\u2022 target_quantum = logical mapping {\u2223bound0\u27e9\u2192\u2223bound0\u27e9, \u2223bound1\u27e9\u2192\u2223bound1\u27e9}  \n\u2022 loss_func = maximize heralding probability subject to teleportation fidelity\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Use qutrit bound\u2010state encoding (three\u2010mode symmetric subspace) for three\u2010level logic  \n\u2022 Chain multiple teleporter nodes to build a repeater network with symmetry\u2010protected links  \n\u2022 Swap standard swapping nodes for bound\u2010state superdense\u2010coding modules to transmit more information per herald click\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The proposal must go beyond re\u2010encoding a qubit in two photons and running a standard swap\u2010based teleporter. Qubit A is encoded in modes 0&1, qubit B in modes 2&3.  To measure even parity (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9), we only mix the \u201cinner\u201d rails 1 & 2 with two vacuum ancilla modes (4,5) in a Pytheus\u2013optimized interferometer that hosts a Fano\u2010resonance\u2013style bound eigenmode: a two\u2010photon state protected by the network\u2019s symmetry.  When modes 1 & 2 carry photons of the same logical value, constructive two\u2010photon interference pumps them into the bound\u2010state channels, which are monitored by detectors 4 & 5.  A joint click heralds even parity and projects the two qubits onto the even\u2010parity subspace, while rails 0 & 3 remain untouched.  The symmetry\u2010protected bound state ensures a higher heralding (absorption) probability than a conventional parity\u2010analyzer built from standard beam\u2010splitters.  This parity\u2010filter primitive can be chained or combined with entanglement\u2010swapping/repeater nodes to build larger symmetry\u2010protected networks.\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Heralded parity\u2010filter on two dual\u2010rail qubits via a symmetry\u2010protected bound\u2010state interferometer\",\n  foldername: \"BoundStateParityFilter\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,                   # two herald detectors monitoring the bound\u2010state outputs\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: False,\n  safe_hist: True,\n  samples: 15,\n  target_quantum: [\"01+10\"],    # the symmetric two-photon bound\u2010state subspace on modes 1&2\n  in_nodes: [1,2],              # only the inner rails (to be parity\u2010measured)\n  out_nodes: [0,3],             # the untouched rails, carrying the post\u2010filtered qubits\n  thresholds: [0.3, 0.1],\n  heralding_out: [4,5],         # detectors at the bound\u2010state channels\n  single_emitters: [],          # qubits are pre\u2010encoded; no SPDC sources needed here\n  removed_connections: [],      # no forbidden source links\u2014input qubits enter directly\n  number_resolving: True,\n  anc_detectors: [4,5]\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2022 Insert this bound-state parity filter as the central node in an entanglement\u2010swapping chain to build a repeater with boosted heralding.  \n \u2022 Extend to multi\u2010rail encodings (qutrit parity checks) by designing C\u2099\u2010symmetric bound\u2010state filters.  \n \u2022 Use the same primitive in measurement\u2010based quantum circuits to reduce ancilla overhead for parity checks or entanglement distillation.\n\nThis target asks Pytheus to find the minimal linear\u2010optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters + ancilla vacuum modes) that (post\u2010selected on clicks at detectors 4,5) implements the projector onto the symmetric (|01\u27e9+|10\u27e9) subspace of modes 1&2, thereby realizing a heralded even\u2010parity measurement with \u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d due to the symmetry\u2010protected bound state."

In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"enhanced light absorption\" and \"symmetry protected bound state\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. Alice holds mode 0, Bob holds mode 3. At Charlie\u2019s station, modes 1 and 2 enter a Pytheus\u2010designed linear\u2010optical network that implements a projection onto the two\u2010photon symmetric subspace Span{|01\u27e9+|10\u27e9}. Successful clicks at Charlie\u2019s two heralding detectors both (a) realize entanglement swapping\u2014leaving modes 0 and 3 in a Bell state\u2014and (b) exploit constructive interference in the symmetry\u2010protected \u201cbound\u2010state\u201d subspace to boost the overall heralding (absorption) rate above that of a standard partial\u2010Bell\u2010measurement distillation. By comparing fidelity and heralding probabilities of this \u201cbound\u2010state\u2013filtered distillation\u201d to a reference distillation using a conventional linear\u2010optical Bell\u2010analyzer, one directly quantifies the enhancement afforded by symmetry protection. This primitive generalizes to multi\u2010pair distillation chains or higher\u2010dimensional symmetric subspaces.\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Entanglement distillation via a symmetry-protected bound-state filter\",\n  foldername: \"BoundStateDistill\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,                      # two heralding detectors at Charlie\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: False,\n  safe_hist: True,\n  samples: 15,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],     # final Bell pair on modes 0 and 3\n  in_nodes: [],                    \n  out_nodes: [0,3],                # Alice\u2019s mode 0 and Bob\u2019s mode 3\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  heralding_out: [1,2],            # Charlie\u2019s detectors on modes 1,2\n  single_emitters: [],             # use SPDC pair sources\n  removed_connections: [],         # no forbidden SPDC links beyond the two defined pairs\n  number_resolving: True,\n  anc_detectors: [1,2]\n}\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To reach PRL novelty, you must propose a measurement or network that cannot be reduced to a symmetric\u2010subspace filter plus entanglement swap.     "output": "Experiment Title: Symmetry\u2010Protected Bound\u2010State Fusion for Enhanced GHZ Entanglement\n\nexplanation:\n  Rather than generating a GHZ state from scratch, we perform a network\u2010level entanglement\u2010fusion of three independent Bell pairs, using a \u201cbound\u2010state filter\u2019\u2019 at the central node that is protected by cyclic (C\u2083) symmetry.  \n  \u2022 Sources: Three SPDC pair sources produce Bell pairs on modes (A\u2013a), (B\u2013b), (C\u2013c). Nodes A, B, C each keep their half of the Bell pair. Modes a, b, c are sent to Charlie.  \n  \u2022 Fusion network: Charlie inputs modes a, b, c plus two ancillary vacuum modes into a Pytheus\u2010optimized five\u2010port linear\u2010optical interferometer engineered to host a three\u2010photon \u201cbound eigenmode\u201d protected by C\u2083 symmetry. When the three incoming photons collectively occupy that bound mode, constructive interference funnels them into two number\u2010resolving herald detectors with anomalously high probability \u2014 an \u201cenhanced light absorption\u2019\u2019 effect.  \n  \u2022 Heralding & fusion: A particular two\u2010click pattern on Charlie\u2019s detectors both (1) projects a three\u2010photon bound\u2010state subspace and (2) fuses the three Bell pairs into a GHZ state among A, B, and C. By benchmarking the post\u2010selected GHZ\u2010fidelity and herald probability against a reference linear\u2010optical fusion circuit (e.g., a plain three\u2010photon projection), one directly measures the absorption enhancement due to the symmetry\u2010protected bound state.  \n  \u2022 Generalization: The same bound\u2010state\u2013fusion module can be cascaded to fuse larger graph\u2010state fragments or extended to higher C\u2099 symmetries for multi\u2010photon entanglement protocols.\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Three\u2010pair entanglement fusion via a C\u2083 symmetry\u2010protected bound\u2010state filter\",\n  foldername: \"BoundState_GHZ_Fusion\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,                       # two heralding detectors at Charlie\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: False,\n  safe_hist: True,\n  samples: 20,\n  target_quantum: [\"000\",\"111\"],    # GHZ subspace on modes A,B,C\n  in_nodes: [],                     \n  out_nodes: [0,1,2],               # A,B,C are out nodes\n  thresholds: [0.2,0.05],\n  heralding_out: [5,6],             # Charlie\u2019s detectors on the bound\u2010state outputs\n  single_emitters: [],              # use three SPDC pair sources\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,1],[0,2],[1,2]               # forbid any direct Bell\u2010source connecting two of A,B,C\n  ],\n  number_resolving: True,\n  anc_detectors: [5,6]\n}\n\nWhy this is novel:\n  \u2013 No existing Pytheus experiment fuses multiple Bell pairs via a topologically or symmetry\u2010protected bound\u2010state filter.  \n  \u2013 The bound\u2010state projector is a genuinely new network primitive\u2014distinct from a standard GHZ-analyzer or three-photon interference\u2014because its C\u2083 symmetry yields an isolated two\u2010click \u201cdark\u201d bound mode that boosts heralding probability.\n\nWhy this is feasible:\n  \u2022 Only SPDC sources, linear optics (beam splitters + phase shifters forming a 5\u2010port mesh), and number\u2010resolving detectors are required\u2014exactly within Pytheus\u2019s design scope.  \n  \u2022 The bound\u2010state subspace lives abstractly in the five\u2010mode Fock space; no physical cavities, nonlinearities, or feedback are needed.  \n  \u2022 Pytheus can optimize the multiport interferometer and ancilla couplings to realize the desired three\u2010photon bound eigenmode projector.\n\nThis proposal shifts the focus from generating a GHZ state to engineering a new fusion *transformation*, revealing how symmetry\u2010protected bound\u2010state interference can enhance heralded entanglement distribution in multi\u2010node quantum networks."

For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. The bound\u2010state encoding enhances heralding rates (\u201cabsorption\u201d) because its symmetric wavefunction couples more efficiently into detectors.\n    2) Entanglement relay in a chain of N nodes: prepare symmetry-protected bound-state entanglement on each link; perform sequential symmetry-respecting Bell measurements to swap entanglement from node 1 to node N. The bound\u2010state structure yields higher cumulative absorption (herald rates) and is robust against photon loss. \n    3) Superdense coding with bound-state qudits: symmetrically encode two classical bits into a two-photon bound state; distribute half the bound-state to Bob via an entanglement\u2010swapping network. Bob decodes by a symmetry-protected measurement that benefits from enhanced absorption cross section.\n\n  Step 2: Novelty and Pytheus obstacles:\n    1) Bound\u2010state-qubit teleportation is not in the explored list; it\u2019s a transformation (teleportation) rather than pure state generation. Pytheus can handle Bell\u2010type swap networks and abstract qubit encodings. Main obstacle: need to define the bound\u2010state basis abstractly and ask Pytheus for the minimal ancilla network.\n    2) N-node relay generalizes entanglement swapping to symmetry-protected resources\u2014novel but more complex; might be too large for initial implementation.\n    3) Superdense coding with bound states is novel but effectively reduces to a Bell-state network plus modified measurement basis; less striking than teleportation of a bound-state.\n\n  Step 3: Pick the bound\u2010state qubit teleportation (option 1) as it is novel, clearly a transformation, sized for Pytheus, and directly showcases enhanced absorption (heralding).\n\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus experiment has teleported a logical qubit encoded in a symmetry-protected two-mode bound state; existing examples swap standard Bell pairs or qutrit pairs, but none exploit a bound-state encoding to boost heralding.\n\n  Step 5: This idea is feasible in Pytheus and satisfies all constraints because:\n    \u2022 It\u2019s a teleportation network (entanglement swapping) with post-selection\u2014Pytheus can design such linear-optical networks.  \n    \u2022 The bound-state encoding is abstract: we simply treat two physical modes at Alice (and Bob) as one logical qubit living in a two-dimensional symmetric subspace.  \n    \u2022 We only require probabilistic pair sources and single-photon emitters, plus heralding detectors\u2014no cavities or feedback.  \n    \u2022 Enhanced absorption is tested by comparing the heralding rate of this network vs. a standard teleportation network.  \n    \u2022 This protocol naturally generalizes to higher dimensions or longer chains of teleportation nodes.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nExperiment Title: Symmetry-Protected Bound\u2010State Qubit Teleportation with Enhanced Heralding\n\nDescription:\nWe encode a logical qubit into two photonic modes at Alice and Bob by restricting to the symmetric two\u2010photon subspace (\u201cbound state\u201d protected by mode\u2010exchange symmetry), which enhances the coupling (absorption) into detectors. We then teleport this bound\u2010state\u2013encoded qubit from Alice to Bob via a central node Charlie using entanglement swapping. By comparing the heralding statistics to a standard teleporter, we directly observe \u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d due to the symmetry\u2010protected bound\u2010state encoding. The network can be generalized to longer chains or higher\u2010dimensional bound\u2010state encodings.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2022 Alice\u2019s logical qubit: two modes A\u2081, A\u2082, with unknown state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 in the symmetric subspace Span{\u222301\u27e9+\u222310\u27e9, \u222300\u27e9, \u222311\u27e9\u2026 restricted to two\u2010dim logical basis}.  \n\u2022 Two SPDC sources produce Bell\u2010pairs: one between modes B\u2081\u2013C\u2081, one between modes B\u2082\u2013C\u2082. Modes C\u2081,C\u2082 are sent to Charlie; modes B\u2081,B\u2082 go to Bob.  \n\u2022 At Alice: her bound\u2010state qubit in A\u2081,A\u2082 plus the two\u2010mode halves of an entangled resource with Charlie (another SPDC) feed into a linear\u2010optical network.  \n\u2022 Charlie performs a joint, symmetry\u2010respecting four\u2013mode Bell measurement on A\u2081,A\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082 (heralding detectors).  \n\u2022 Upon a specific click pattern, the bound\u2010state qubit is teleported to Bob\u2019s modes B\u2081,B\u2082, still within the symmetric subspace.  \n\u2022 We record both teleportation fidelity and heralding rate\u2014enhanced absorption manifests as higher post\u2010selected rates for bound\u2010state encoding vs. standard dual\u2010rail encoding.\n\nKey Pytheus Config Elements (to be found by Expert):\n\u2022 num_anc = detectors at Charlie  \n\u2022 single_emitters or pair_sources for each SPDC link  \n\u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct ties from Alice to Bob  \n\u2022 target_quantum = logical mapping {\u2223bound0\u27e9\u2192\u2223bound0\u27e9, \u2223bound1\u27e9\u2192\u2223bound1\u27e9}  \n\u2022 loss_func = maximize heralding probability subject to teleportation fidelity\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Use qutrit bound\u2010state encoding (three\u2010mode symmetric subspace) for three\u2010level logic  \n\u2022 Chain multiple teleporter nodes to build a repeater network with symmetry\u2010protected links  \n\u2022 Swap standard swapping nodes for bound\u2010state superdense\u2010coding modules to transmit more information per herald click\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The proposal must go beyond re\u2010encoding a qubit in two photons and running a standard swap\u2010based teleporter. Sequential swapping yields higher overall heralding (absorption) efficiency and loss resilience.\n 3) Superdense coding: encode two classical bits into a two\u2010photon bound state protected by spatial-mode symmetry, then send one half through a swapping network and decode via a symmetry-protected Bell measurement.\n\nStep 2: Novelty & obstacles\n 1) Not in the explored list. The only subtlety is defining the bound-state logical basis abstractly.\n 2) More complex and large, may exceed a first Pytheus run.\n 3) Reduces to a Bell-analyzer plus resources\u2014interesting but less striking than teleporting a bound-state qubit.\n\nStep 3: Pick idea #1.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus experiment has teleported a logical qubit encoded in a symmetry-protected two-photon bound state, nor compared heralding efficiency to a standard teleportation.\n\nStep 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework because\n \u2022 It is a post-selected entanglement-swapping (teleportation) network using only probabilistic pair sources and linear optics.\n \u2022 The bound-state encoding sits purely in the abstract two-mode symmetric subspace, so Pytheus can treat it as a qubit without needing physical implementation details.\n \u2022 We only require a four-mode Bell analyzer at Charlie (Pytheus excels at designing such measurement circuits), and heralded detectors.\n \u2022 No dynamic feedback or cavities are needed\u2014completely within Pytheus\u2019s domain.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nExperiment Title: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Qubit Teleportation\n\nexplanation:\n  We encode a logical qubit into two photonic modes (Alice\u2019s modes A\u2080,A\u2081) by restricting to their symmetric subspace (\u201cbound state,\u201d protected by mode-exchange symmetry). A standard Bell-pair source creates an entangled resource between Charlie\u2019s modes C\u2080,C\u2081 and Bob\u2019s modes B\u2080,B\u2081. By comparing the heralding probability and teleportation fidelity of this bound-state scheme to a reference dual-rail teleportation, one directly observes \u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d (higher post-selection rates) due to the symmetry-protected bound state. This mesh hosts a symmetry-protected two-photon \u201cedge bound state\u201d localized at one boundary port. When two photons arrive simultaneously in the bulk, they preferentially occupy that bound mode via constructive interference\u2014an effective \u201cenhanced absorption.\u201d Two number-resolving detectors monitoring the boundary mode herald (a) successful entanglement swapping between modes 0 and 3 and (b) an elevated heralding probability compared to a conventional two-port Bell-analyzer. Alice holds mode 0, Bob holds mode 3. At Charlie\u2019s station, modes 1 and 2 are mixed with two ancillary vacuum modes (4,5) in a Pytheus\u2010designed linear\u2010optical multiport engineered to host a Fano\u2010resonance\u2013style bound state: a symmetry\u2010protected two\u2010photon eigenmode embedded in the continuum of four-port network. When two photons enter the multiport, they preferentially occupy that bound mode and emerge at two heralding detectors monitoring the bound\u2010state outputs. A click pattern on detectors 4 and 5 both (a) implements entanglement swapping\u2014leaving modes 0 and 3 in a Bell state\u2014and (b) exhibits an elevated heralding probability (\u201cenhanced absorption\u201d) compared to a conventional two\u2010port Bell analyzer. By benchmarking swap fidelity and heralding rates against a reference swap circuit, one directly quantifies the absorption enhancement due to the Fano bound state. Pytheus can design the four-mode linear-optical projector plus heralding detectors. \n    2) Option 2 is intriguing but pushes Pytheus toward multipartite teleportation complexity. \n    3) Option 3 is scalable but may exceed a first-run resource budget.\n\n  Step 3: Select option 1.\n\n  Step 4: This is novel because it embeds a genuine symmetry-protected bound-state filter into entanglement purification, realizing a single-step distillation that both swaps and purifies Bell pairs with an enhanced herald probability\u2014a primitive absent from all existing Pytheus networks.\n\n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus:\n    \u2022 Uses only two SPDC sources, linear optics, number-resolving detectors, post-selection.\n    \u2022 The bound-state filter is an abstract two-photon symmetric subspace projector\u2014Pytheus can optimize it without physical encoding details.\n    \u2022 No cavities or feedback needed\u2014entirely within Pytheus\u2019s design space.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nExperiment Title: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Entanglement Purification\n\nexplanation:\n  We begin with two imperfect SPDC-generated Bell pairs on modes (0,1) and (2,3). Alice holds mode 0, Bob holds mode 3. Charlie receives modes 1 and 2. Instead of a standard Bell measurement, Charlie\u2019s station implements a linear-optical projector onto the two-photon symmetric subspace Span{|01\u27e9+|10\u27e9}\u2014a \u201cbound-state filter\u201d protected by exchange symmetry. Successful coincident clicks on Charlie\u2019s two herald detectors both (a) swap entanglement\u2014leaving modes 0 and 3 in a purified Bell state\u2014and (b) exhibit an enhanced heralding probability due to constructive interference in the symmetry-protected bound subspace. By comparing fidelity and post-selection rates against a reference purification circuit using a conventional Bell-analyzer, one directly quantifies the \u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d afforded by the symmetry-protected bound-state filter. This primitive generalizes to multi-pair distillation or chained repeater links.\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description:   \"Entanglement purification via a symmetry-protected two-photon bound-state filter\",\n  foldername:    \"BoundStatePurify\",\n  bulk_thr:      0.01,\n  edges_tried:   25,\n  ftol:          1e-06,\n  loss_func:     \"cr\",\n  num_anc:       2,                 # two heralding detectors at Charlie\n  num_pre:       1,\n  optimizer:     \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary:     False,\n  safe_hist:     True,\n  samples:       15,\n  target_quantum:[\"00\",\"11\"],        # purified Bell pair on modes 0 and 3\n  in_nodes:      [],                 \n  out_nodes:     [0,3],              # Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s modes\n  thresholds:    [0.3,0.1],\n  heralding_out: [1,2],              # Charlie\u2019s detectors on modes 1 & 2\n  single_emitters:[],\n  removed_connections: [[0,3],[1,2]],# only SPDC links (0\u21941) & (2\u21943)\n  number_resolving:True,\n  anc_detectors: [1,2]\n}"

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target measurement-induced photonic quantum SWITCH of two entanglement-breaking dephasing channels using ancilla photons, passive linear optics, and post-selection to emulate a discrete cross-Kerr coupling between a control and two data paths. Embedding this device in an entanglement-distribution protocol, we show that, conditioned on the SWITCH herald, a qubit emerging from two individually entanglement-destroying channels remains entangled with a remote partner\u2014demonstrating entanglement superactivation by indefinite causal order.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Encoded entirely in the Pytheus framework using beam splitters, phase shifters and number-resolving detectors, the scheme allows optimization of local measurement phases to maximize violation of Fritz\u2019s triangle network Bell inequality in a mixed-frequency architecture.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: PT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\n\nAbstract: We implement entanglement swapping on two polarization-encoded Bell pairs using a central PT-symmetric, non-unitary Bell-state analyser. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe demonstrate a heralded, non-unitary PT-symmetric gain\u2013loss filter embedded in the Bell-state measurement of a teleportation-based CNOT between photonic qubit A (control) and qubit C (target). By using SPDC-pair ancillas, four-port interferometric mixing, and number-resolving detection to preferentially amplify even-parity Bell components, our scheme surpasses the 50% passive-linear-optics limit and boosts both the success probability and fidelity of the nonlocal CNOT gate.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. By steering both B\u2080 and C\u2080 through unknown multimode scattering channels U\u2081,U\u2082 with programmable wavefront shapers and performing a single ancilla\u2010mediated parity filter across the combined outputs, an even-parity detection event heralds successful entanglement percolation without ever fully inverting the scattering matrices.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. We then teleport this bound\u2010state\u2013encoded qubit from Alice to Bob via a central node Charlie using entanglement swapping. By comparing the heralding statistics to a standard teleporter, we directly observe \u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d due to the symmetry\u2010protected bound\u2010state encoding. The network can be generalized to longer chains or higher\u2010dimensional bound\u2010state encodings.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2022 Alice\u2019s logical qubit: two modes A\u2081, A\u2082, with unknown state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 in the symmetric subspace Span{\u222301\u27e9+\u222310\u27e9, \u222300\u27e9, \u222311\u27e9\u2026 restricted to two\u2010dim logical basis}.  \n\u2022 Two SPDC sources produce Bell\u2010pairs: one between modes B\u2081\u2013C\u2081, one between modes B\u2082\u2013C\u2082. Alice holds mode 0, Bob holds mode 3. At Charlie\u2019s node, modes 1 and 2 are fed into a C\u2083-symmetric three-port linear-optical interferometer whose design is optimized by Pytheus. This interferometer has one special two-photon eigenmode\u2014a \u201cbound state\u201d\u2014protected by its three-fold rotational symmetry. When the incoming photons from modes 1 and 2 occupy that bound subspace, interference directs them with anomalously high probability into two heralding detectors. A click pattern on Charlie\u2019s detectors simultaneously (a) entangles modes 0 and 3 (entanglement swap) and (b) exhibits an enhanced heralding probability (\u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d) versus a conventional two-port Bell-analyzer. By comparing both swap-fidelity and heralding rates against a reference linear-optical swap, one directly measures the absorption enhancement due to the symmetry-protected bound state. This bound-state swap module naturally generalizes to chains of nodes for repeaters or to higher-mode cyclic symmetries (C\u2084, C\u2085, \u2026).\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Entanglement swap via a symmetry\u2010protected C\u2083 bound\u2010state filter\",\n  foldername: \"BoundStateSwap_C3\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,                         # two herald detectors at Charlie\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: False,\n  safe_hist: True,\n  samples: 15,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],        # post\u2010selected Bell on modes 0 and 3\n  in_nodes: [],\n  out_nodes: [0,3],\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  heralding_out: [1,2],               # Charlie\u2019s detectors\n  single_emitters: [],                # two SPDC pair sources only\n  removed_connections: [],            # sources only link (0,1) and (2,3)\n  number_resolving: True,\n  anc_detectors: [1,2],\n}\n\nThis network leverages Pytheus\u2019s ability to find the optimal linear-optical three-port implementing the non-trivial bound\u2010state projector, inserted as the swap measurement.
