This falls squarely into the class of multiport bunching filters (generalized HOM designs) and partial Bell analyzers that are already well known, and the protocol reduces to entanglement swapping plus coincidence gating. There is no genuinely new measurement\u2010induced map, no emergent nonperturbative photon\u2013photon bound\u2010state physics, nor a network primitive that cannot be implemented by existing linear-optical Bell-measurement techniques.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To be novel, you need to identify a transformation or bound-state phenomenon that cannot be emulated by standard symmetric-subspace filters. For instance, propose a non-Hermitian or topologically protected bound-mode operation, or exploit a true photon-photon bound state in a nonlinear or synthetic quantum material that yields an unimplemented network primitive. Provide a clear target map or effect that goes beyond simply boosting heralding by using extra symmetric modes.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Experiment Title: Topology-Induced Bound-State Entanglement Swapping\n\nexplanation:\n  We start from two independent SPDC sources emitting Bell pairs on modes (0,1) and (2,3). Alice holds mode 0, Bob holds mode 3. At Charlie\u2019s node, modes 1 and 2 enter a Pytheus-designed linear-optical multiport consisting of four internal modes arranged with alternating beam-splitter couplings (an SSH chain). This mesh hosts a symmetry-protected two-photon \u201cedge bound state\u201d localized at one boundary port. When two photons arrive simultaneously in the bulk, they preferentially occupy that bound mode via constructive interference\u2014an effective \u201cenhanced absorption.\u201d Two number-resolving detectors monitoring the boundary mode herald (a) successful entanglement swapping between modes 0 and 3 and (b) an elevated heralding probability compared to a conventional two-port Bell-analyzer. By benchmarking swap fidelity and heralding rates against a standard swap circuit, one directly quantifies the absorption enhancement due to the symmetry-protected bound state. This bound-state swap module naturally generalizes to longer chains (higher-order topologies) or multi-node repeater networks.\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Entanglement swap via a topology-inspired symmetry-protected bound-state filter\",\n  foldername: \"TopoBoundSwap\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,                      # two herald detectors at the boundary port\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: False,\n  safe_hist: True,\n  samples: 20,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],     # Alice\u2019s mode 0 & Bob\u2019s mode 3 in a Bell subspace\n  in_nodes: [],                    \n  out_nodes: [0,3],\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  heralding_out: [4,5],            # detectors at the bound\u2010state boundary ports\n  single_emitters: [],             # two SPDC sources only\n  removed_connections: [[0,3],[1,2]],   # forbid any cross-pair SPDC links\n  number_resolving: True,\n  anc_detectors: [4,5]\n}\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed \u201ctopology\u2010induced\u201d bound\u2010state filter is just a passive linear\u2010optical multiport (an SSH\u2010inspired beam\u2010splitter network) used to bunch two photons into a boundary mode, followed by post-selected entanglement swapping. It does not introduce a new network primitive or exploit truly novel topological bound\u2010mode physics.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To be novel, you must propose a transformation that cannot be realized as a simple symmetric\u2010subspace projector plus entanglement swap\u2014for example a genuine non\u2010Hermitian or interacting topological two\u2010photon bound state, or a measurement that enacts a new nontrivial map beyond existing Bell measurements. Show a concrete mechanism where topology or interactions yield a measurement\u2010induced effect unattainable by standard linear\u2010optical swaps.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Experiment Title: Fano\u2010Bound\u2010State Filtered Entanglement Swapping\n\nexplanation:\n  Two independent SPDC sources produce Bell pairs on modes (0,1) and (2,3). Alice holds mode 0, Bob holds mode 3. At Charlie\u2019s station, modes 1 and 2 are mixed with two ancillary vacuum modes (4,5) in a Pytheus\u2010designed linear\u2010optical multiport engineered to host a Fano\u2010resonance\u2013style bound state: a symmetry\u2010protected two\u2010photon eigenmode embedded in the continuum of four-port network. When two photons enter the multiport, they preferentially occupy that bound mode and emerge at two heralding detectors monitoring the bound\u2010state outputs. A click pattern on detectors 4 and 5 both (a) implements entanglement swapping\u2014leaving modes 0 and 3 in a Bell state\u2014and (b) exhibits an elevated heralding probability (\u201cenhanced absorption\u201d) compared to a conventional two\u2010port Bell analyzer. By benchmarking swap fidelity and heralding rates against a reference swap circuit, one directly quantifies the absorption enhancement due to the Fano bound state.     "output": "Thought: The proposed \u201csymmetry\u2010protected bound\u2010state\u201d purifier is nothing more than a standard symmetric\u2010subspace (bunching) projector combined with an entanglement\u2010swapping/distillation step. The bound\u2010state structure yields higher cumulative absorption (herald rates) and is robust against photon loss. \n    3) Superdense coding with bound-state qudits: symmetrically encode two classical bits into a two-photon bound state; distribute half the bound-state to Bob via an entanglement\u2010swapping network. Bob decodes by a symmetry-protected measurement that benefits from enhanced absorption cross section.\n\n  Step 2: Novelty and Pytheus obstacles:\n    1) Bound\u2010state-qubit teleportation is not in the explored list; it\u2019s a transformation (teleportation) rather than pure state generation. Pytheus can optimize a three-port linear-optical network plus ancilla detectors to implement any desired projection. \n 2) Option #2 reduces to a teleportation variant\u2014less network-primitive novelty.\n 3) Option #3 is interesting but resource-heavy and complex for a first demonstration.\n\nStep 3: Choose Option #1.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it promotes a genuine symmetry-protected bound-state eigenmode\u2014realized by a C\u2083-symmetric multiport\u2014as the measurement primitive in entanglement swapping. The bound eigenmode is a non-trivial two-photon \u201cbound state\u201d in a continuum of three spatial channels, and its protected interference enhances heralding. No previous Pytheus example has realized this kind of projector or used it to boost swap success.\n\nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because:\n \u2022 It uses two SPDC pair sources (modes 0\u20131 and 2\u20133) and linear optics only.\n \u2022 The core is a 3-input, 3-output interferometer (the bound-state filter) plus number-resolving detectors\u2014well within Pytheus\u2019s design space.\n \u2022 The bound-state appears purely as an abstract two-photon subspace of the three-mode multiport; Pytheus doesn\u2019t need physical encoding details.\n \u2022 No dynamic feedback, cavities or nonlinear media are required\u2014only probabilistic sources, beam splitters, phase shifters and detectors.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nExperiment Title: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Filtered Entanglement Swapping\n\nexplanation:\n  We begin with two independent SPDC sources creating Bell pairs on modes (0,1) and (2,3). Alice holds mode 0, Bob holds mode 3. At Charlie\u2019s node, modes 1 and 2 are fed into a C\u2083-symmetric three-port linear-optical interferometer whose design is optimized by Pytheus. This interferometer has one special two-photon eigenmode\u2014a \u201cbound state\u201d\u2014protected by its three-fold rotational symmetry. When the incoming photons from modes 1 and 2 occupy that bound subspace, interference directs them with anomalously high probability into two heralding detectors. A click pattern on Charlie\u2019s detectors simultaneously (a) entangles modes 0 and 3 (entanglement swap) and (b) exhibits an enhanced heralding probability (\u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d) versus a conventional two-port Bell-analyzer. By comparing both swap-fidelity and heralding rates against a reference linear-optical swap, one directly measures the absorption enhancement due to the symmetry-protected bound state. This bound state resonantly concentrates amplitude into heralding detectors, boosting swap success (\u201cabsorption\u201d).\n    2) Single-step entanglement purification via a cyclic-symmetry bound-state projector: two noisy Bell pairs are distilled by a three-port filter that only passes the cyclically symmetric two-photon bound mode, enhancing herald probability over standard distillation.\n    3) A two-link repeater chain where each link employs a topology-induced bound-state filter to sequentially swap entanglement with cumulative absorption enhancement.\n  Step 2: Novelty & feasibility:\n    1) Option 1 is novel: no existing Pytheus example uses a genuine three-photon bound-state resonance as the swap measurement primitive. Pytheus can design the required multiport and heralding detectors with SPDC and single-photon sources.\n    2) Option 2 is similar to prior symmetric-subspace filters; less network-primitive novelty.\n    3) Option 3 is scalable but too large for a first demonstration.\n  Step 3: Choose option 1.\n  Step 4: Novelty: embedding a Feshbach-type three-photon bound-state resonance into entanglement swapping yields a fundamentally new, non-Hermitian effective measurement that boosts heralding beyond any linear-optical Bell analyzer.\n  Step 5: Feasibility: uses only two SPDC sources, one single-photon emitter, linear optics, and number-resolving detectors\u2014entirely within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities. The bound state is an abstract three-photon eigenmode of the multiport, so no physical encoding details are needed.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nExperiment Title: Three-Photon Bound-State\u2013Assisted Entanglement Swapping\n\nexplanation:\n  We start with two SPDC pair sources producing Bell pairs on modes (0,1) and (2,3). A single-photon emitter injects an ancilla photon into mode 4. At Charlie\u2019s node, modes 1, 2, and 4 interfere in a Pytheus-optimized multiport engineered to host a Feshbach-type three-photon bound state\u2014an eigenmode sharply localized by destructive interference with the \u201cscattering\u201d continuum. When the three photons collectively occupy that bound mode, they almost deterministically exit into two heralding detectors monitoring the bound-state outputs. A coincident click pattern both (a) swaps entanglement between modes 0 and 3 (leaving them in a Bell state) and (b) exhibits an enhanced heralding probability (\u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d) compared to a standard two-photon Bell analyzer. By benchmarking success rate and swap fidelity against the reference protocol, one directly quantifies the absorption enhancement imparted by the symmetry-protected bound state.     "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target measurement-induced photonic quantum SWITCH of two entanglement-breaking dephasing channels using ancilla photons, passive linear optics, and post-selection to emulate a discrete cross-Kerr coupling between a control and two data paths. Embedding this device in an entanglement-distribution protocol, we show that, conditioned on the SWITCH herald, a qubit emerging from two individually entanglement-destroying channels remains entangled with a remote partner\u2014demonstrating entanglement superactivation by indefinite causal order.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Encoded entirely in the Pytheus framework using beam splitters, phase shifters and number-resolving detectors, the scheme allows optimization of local measurement phases to maximize violation of Fritz\u2019s triangle network Bell inequality in a mixed-frequency architecture.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: PT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\n\nAbstract: We implement entanglement swapping on two polarization-encoded Bell pairs using a central PT-symmetric, non-unitary Bell-state analyser. By heralding the projector onto the PT-modified Bell state (the target map) and tuning its gain/loss parameter \u03b3, the protocol controllably generates a two-photon output |\u03a8_AD\u27e9\u221d|HH\u27e9+\u03b3\u2009e^{i\u03d5}|VV\u27e9 with adjustable, non-maximal entanglement.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe demonstrate a heralded, non-unitary PT-symmetric gain\u2013loss filter embedded in the Bell-state measurement of a teleportation-based CNOT between photonic qubit A (control) and qubit C (target). By using SPDC-pair ancillas, four-port interferometric mixing, and number-resolving detection to preferentially amplify even-parity Bell components, our scheme surpasses the 50% passive-linear-optics limit and boosts both the success probability and fidelity of the nonlocal CNOT gate.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Using three probabilistic EPR sources, linear-optics routing into two Bell-measurement stations, and post-selection on the control measurement, this experiment realizes the target entanglement-switch quantum switch primitive without state-generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nMulti-Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present an all\u2010linear\u2010optical protocol, \u201cMulti\u2010Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering,\u201d that fuses two Bell pairs A\u2013B\u2080 and C\u2080\u2013D into a high-fidelity link between remote photons A and D. By steering both B\u2080 and C\u2080 through unknown multimode scattering channels U\u2081,U\u2082 with programmable wavefront shapers and performing a single ancilla\u2010mediated parity filter across the combined outputs, an even-parity detection event heralds successful entanglement percolation without ever fully inverting the scattering matrices.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Continuous Topological Phase Transition of a Kitaev 1D Majorana Chain via Bell-Measurement Tuning in a Linear-Optical Entanglement-Swapping Network\n\nMini-abstract: We propose and simulate in Pytheus a linear-optical quantum network of probabilistic photon-pair sources and intermediate Bell-state measurements whose beam-splitter reflectivity r acts as a continuous control parameter, reproducing the continuous topological phase transition of the target Kitaev 1D Majorana chain. As r crosses a critical threshold r_c, long-range end-to-end entanglement between edge nodes A and Z suddenly emerges, faithfully mapping onto the onset of Majorana zero-mode correlations in the original topological model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Cyclic Indefinite\u2010Order Entanglement\u2010Swapping Switch for the Three-State Bargmann Invariant\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static linear-optical network that path-controls a single photon to cyclically superpose three successive Bell\u2013swap orders among unknown qubits A, B, and C, recombining all nine modes in a fixed nine-port interferometer and reading out a binary \u201c+\u201d/\u201c\u2013\u201d outcome. The target is the real part of the three-state Bargmann invariant Re\u2009Tr(\u03c1_A\u2009\u03c1_B\u2009\u03c1_C), whose quantized response statistics directly realize a genuine three-point quantum metric beyond pairwise SWAP tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Collision\u2010Mode Photonic MPO Simulation of Lindblad Open\u2010System Dynamics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose a static one\u2010dimensional photonic matrix\u2010product\u2010operator (MPO) network\u2014built from probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, tunable beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014to stroboscopically enact the small\u2010time Kraus maps E_k = e^{L\u0394t} that realize the target Lindblad generator L over total time T = N\u0394t. By performing a two-copy SWAP-test on the network\u2019s outputs, four-fold coincidence rates directly yield the second-R\u00e9nyi entanglement negativity \u221d|S\u208di,j\u208e|\u00b2, providing an operational readout of topological data using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, static interferometers, phase-shifters, and number-resolving detectors in Pytheus.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Experiment Title: Symmetry-Protected Bound\u2010State Qubit Teleportation with Enhanced Heralding\n\nDescription:\nWe encode a logical qubit into two photonic modes at Alice and Bob by restricting to the symmetric two\u2010photon subspace (\u201cbound state\u201d protected by mode\u2010exchange symmetry), which enhances the coupling (absorption) into detectors. We then teleport this bound\u2010state\u2013encoded qubit from Alice to Bob via a central node Charlie using entanglement swapping. By comparing the heralding statistics to a standard teleporter, we directly observe \u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d due to the symmetry\u2010protected bound\u2010state encoding. The network can be generalized to longer chains or higher\u2010dimensional bound\u2010state encodings.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2022 Alice\u2019s logical qubit: two modes A\u2081, A\u2082, with unknown state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 in the symmetric subspace Span{\u222301\u27e9+\u222310\u27e9, \u222300\u27e9, \u222311\u27e9\u2026 restricted to two\u2010dim logical basis}.  \n\u2022 Two SPDC sources produce Bell\u2010pairs: one between modes B\u2081\u2013C\u2081, one between modes B\u2082\u2013C\u2082. Modes C\u2081,C\u2082 are sent to Charlie; modes B\u2081,B\u2082 go to Bob.  \n\u2022 At Alice: her bound\u2010state qubit in A\u2081,A\u2082 plus the two\u2010mode halves of an entangled resource with Charlie (another SPDC) feed into a linear\u2010optical network.  \n\u2022 Charlie performs a joint, symmetry\u2010respecting four\u2013mode Bell measurement on A\u2081,A\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082 (heralding detectors).  \n\u2022 Upon a specific click pattern, the bound\u2010state qubit is teleported to Bob\u2019s modes B\u2081,B\u2082, still within the symmetric subspace.  \n\u2022 We record both teleportation fidelity and heralding rate\u2014enhanced absorption manifests as higher post\u2010selected rates for bound\u2010state encoding vs. standard dual\u2010rail encoding.\n\nKey Pytheus Config Elements (to be found by Expert):\n\u2022 num_anc = detectors at Charlie  \n\u2022 single_emitters or pair_sources for each SPDC link  \n\u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct ties from Alice to Bob  \n\u2022 target_quantum = logical mapping {\u2223bound0\u27e9\u2192\u2223bound0\u27e9, \u2223bound1\u27e9\u2192\u2223bound1\u27e9}  \n\u2022 loss_func = maximize heralding probability subject to teleportation fidelity\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Use qutrit bound\u2010state encoding (three\u2010mode symmetric subspace) for three\u2010level logic  \n\u2022 Chain multiple teleporter nodes to build a repeater network with symmetry\u2010protected links  \n\u2022 Swap standard swapping nodes for bound\u2010state superdense\u2010coding modules to transmit more information per herald click\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While teleporting a two-photon \u201cbound\u2010state\u201d logical qubit via swapping and comparing heralding rates is an interesting twist on dual\u2010rail teleportation, it does not introduce a genuinely new measurement\u2010induced transformation or network primitive beyond existing entanglement\u2010swapping/teleportation variants. Encoding in the symmetric two\u2010photon subspace is essentially a straightforward extension of multi\u2010mode teleportation, and the claimed \u201cenhanced absorption\u201d lacks a clear mechanism that distinguishes it from simply having two photons available for heralding. Alice and Charlie perform a joint four-mode Bell measurement that respects the same symmetry, heralding teleportation of the bound-state qubit from A\u2080,A\u2081 to B\u2080,B\u2081. By comparing the heralding probability and teleportation fidelity of this bound-state scheme to a reference dual-rail teleportation, one directly observes \u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d (higher post-selection rates) due to the symmetry-protected bound state. This interferometer has one special two-photon eigenmode\u2014a \u201cbound state\u201d\u2014protected by its three-fold rotational symmetry. When the incoming photons from modes 1 and 2 occupy that bound subspace, interference directs them with anomalously high probability into two heralding detectors. A click pattern on Charlie\u2019s detectors simultaneously (a) entangles modes 0 and 3 (entanglement swap) and (b) exhibits an enhanced heralding probability (\u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d) versus a conventional two-port Bell-analyzer. By comparing both swap-fidelity and heralding rates against a reference linear-optical swap, one directly measures the absorption enhancement due to the symmetry-protected bound state. {
    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. The bound\u2010state encoding enhances heralding rates (\u201cabsorption\u201d) because its symmetric wavefunction couples more efficiently into detectors.\n    2) Entanglement relay in a chain of N nodes: prepare symmetry-protected bound-state entanglement on each link; perform sequential symmetry-respecting Bell measurements to swap entanglement from node 1 to node N. The bound\u2010state structure yields higher cumulative absorption (herald rates) and is robust against photon loss. \n    3) Superdense coding with bound-state qudits: symmetrically encode two classical bits into a two-photon bound state; distribute half the bound-state to Bob via an entanglement\u2010swapping network. Bob decodes by a symmetry-protected measurement that benefits from enhanced absorption cross section.\n\n  Step 2: Novelty and Pytheus obstacles:\n    1) Bound\u2010state-qubit teleportation is not in the explored list; it\u2019s a transformation (teleportation) rather than pure state generation. Pytheus can handle Bell\u2010type swap networks and abstract qubit encodings. Main obstacle: need to define the bound\u2010state basis abstractly and ask Pytheus for the minimal ancilla network.\n    2) N-node relay generalizes entanglement swapping to symmetry-protected resources\u2014novel but more complex; might be too large for initial implementation.\n    3) Superdense coding with bound states is novel but effectively reduces to a Bell-state network plus modified measurement basis; less striking than teleportation of a bound-state.\n\n  Step 3: Pick the bound\u2010state qubit teleportation (option 1) as it is novel, clearly a transformation, sized for Pytheus, and directly showcases enhanced absorption (heralding).\n\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no previous Pytheus experiment has teleported a logical qubit encoded in a symmetry-protected two-mode bound state; We then teleport this bound\u2010state\u2013encoded qubit from Alice to Bob via a central node Charlie using entanglement swapping. By comparing the heralding statistics to a standard teleporter, we directly observe \u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d due to the symmetry\u2010protected bound\u2010state encoding. The network can be generalized to longer chains or higher\u2010dimensional bound\u2010state encodings.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2022 Alice\u2019s logical qubit: two modes A\u2081, A\u2082, with unknown state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 in the symmetric subspace Span{\u222301\u27e9+\u222310\u27e9, \u222300\u27e9, \u222311\u27e9\u2026 restricted to two\u2010dim logical basis}.  \n\u2022 Two SPDC sources produce Bell\u2010pairs: one between modes B\u2081\u2013C\u2081, one between modes B\u2082\u2013C\u2082. Modes C\u2081,C\u2082 are sent to Charlie; modes B\u2081,B\u2082 go to Bob.  \n\u2022 At Alice: her bound\u2010state qubit in A\u2081,A\u2082 plus the two\u2010mode halves of an entangled resource with Charlie (another SPDC) feed into a linear\u2010optical network.  \n\u2022 Charlie performs a joint, symmetry\u2010respecting four\u2013mode Bell measurement on A\u2081,A\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082 (heralding detectors).  \n\u2022 Upon a specific click pattern, the bound\u2010state qubit is teleported to Bob\u2019s modes B\u2081,B\u2082, still within the symmetric subspace.  \n\u2022 We record both teleportation fidelity and heralding rate\u2014enhanced absorption manifests as higher post\u2010selected rates for bound\u2010state encoding vs. standard dual\u2010rail encoding.\n\nKey Pytheus Config Elements (to be found by Expert):\n\u2022 num_anc = detectors at Charlie  \n\u2022 single_emitters or pair_sources for each SPDC link  \n\u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct ties from Alice to Bob  \n\u2022 target_quantum = logical mapping {\u2223bound0\u27e9\u2192\u2223bound0\u27e9, \u2223bound1\u27e9\u2192\u2223bound1\u27e9}  \n\u2022 loss_func = maximize heralding probability subject to teleportation fidelity\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Use qutrit bound\u2010state encoding (three\u2010mode symmetric subspace) for three\u2010level logic  \n\u2022 Chain multiple teleporter nodes to build a repeater network with symmetry\u2010protected links  \n\u2022 Swap standard swapping nodes for bound\u2010state superdense\u2010coding modules to transmit more information per herald click\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The proposal must go beyond re\u2010encoding a qubit in two photons and running a standard swap\u2010based teleporter. A standard Bell-pair source creates an entangled resource between Charlie\u2019s modes C\u2080,C\u2081 and Bob\u2019s modes B\u2080,B\u2081. Alice and Charlie perform a joint four-mode Bell measurement that respects the same symmetry, heralding teleportation of the bound-state qubit from A\u2080,A\u2081 to B\u2080,B\u2081. By comparing the heralding probability and teleportation fidelity of this bound-state scheme to a reference dual-rail teleportation, one directly observes \u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d (higher post-selection rates) due to the symmetry-protected bound state. The protocol can be extended to higher-dimensional bound-states or chained repeater links.\n\nconfig:\n  {\n    description: \"Teleport a symmetry-protected bound-state qubit via entanglement swapping\",\n    foldername: \"BoundStateTeleport\",\n    bulk_thr: 0.01,\n    edges_tried: 30,\n    ftol: 1e-06,\n    loss_func: \"cr\",\n    num_anc: 4,                   # four heralding detectors at Charlie\n    num_pre: 1,\n    optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n    imaginary: False,\n    safe_hist: True,\n    samples: 20,\n    target_quantum: [\n      \"0000+1100\",   # |A0A1,C0C1> = |00,00> + |11,00>\n      \"0000-1100\",   # |\u03a6\u00b1> in symmetric subspace\n      \"0011+1111\",   # |00,11> + |11,11>\n      \"0011-1111\"\n    ],\n    in_nodes: [0,1,2,3],         # A0,A1,C0,C1\n    out_nodes: [],               # no fixed outputs; we only care about herald pattern\n    thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n    heralding_out: [0,1,2,3],    # detectors at Charlie\n    single_emitters: [],         # use SPDC pair sources\n    amplitudes: [],\n    tries_per_edge: 5,\n    removed_connections: [],     # Charlie\u2019s measurement only couples local modes\n    number_resolving: True,\n    anc_detectors: []\n  }\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be PRL-worthy, you need a genuinely new target: for example a teleportation or network operation that uniquely exploits nonperturbative photon-photon bound states, topological protection, or a symmetry-induced non-unitary map that has no analog in existing swapping protocols.     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm 3 Pytheus-compatible ways to fuse \u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d and \u201csymmetry-protected bound state\u201d into a network transformation (no pure state generation):\n    1) A **bound-state selective quantum scissor**: a non-unitary amplifier that noiselessly amplifies only the two-photon symmetric (\u201cbound\u201d) subspace before an entanglement-swap, boosting heralding (\u201cabsorption\u201d) beyond a standard Bell measurement.  \n    2) A **topological three-port bound-state filter** inside an entanglement-distillation: use an SSH\u2013like multiport to host a symmetry-protected two-photon edge mode as the distillation primitive, giving enhanced swap+purify success.  \n    3) A **cyclic-symmetry multipartite teleport**: project three photons onto a C\u2083 bound eigenmode to teleport one qubit to two receivers with enhanced absorption into the bound channel.  \n  Step 2: All three are novel relative to prior Pytheus examples. Option 1 is the most sharply defined network primitive\u2014a non-unitary amplifier (quantum scissor) targeted at the bound subspace\u2014yet fully implementable with SPDC, a single-photon emitter, beam splitters and detectors.  \n  Step 3: Select Option 1.  \n  Step 4: Novelty: No existing Pytheus experiment builds a **bound-state-selective quantum scissor**\u2014a linear-optical network that amplifies only the symmetric two-photon subspace\u2014then embeds it in an entanglement-swap. This realizes a genuinely new non-unitary map and directly probes \u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d through heralding rates.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility: Pytheus can optimize beam splitter/phase networks plus ancilla sources and number-resolving detectors to implement any desired Kraus operator on a small mode set. All building blocks\u2014SPDC pair sources, single-photon emitters, linear optics and post-selection\u2014are in its toolbox; no cavities or feedback are needed.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nExperiment Title: Bound-State-Selective Quantum Scissor for Enhanced Teleportation\n\nexplanation:\n  We teleport a logical qubit encoded in two modes A\u2080,A\u2081 (Alice) to Bob\u2019s mode B via entanglement swapping at Charlie, but we first pass the two ancilla photons through a **symmetry-protected quantum scissor** that noiselessly amplifies only the two-photon symmetric (\u201cbound\u201d) subspace. Concretely:\n   1) Two SPDC sources emit Bell pairs on modes (A\u2081,C\u2081) and (A\u2082,C\u2082). Alice holds A\u2081,A\u2082; Charlie receives C\u2081,C\u2082.  \n   2) An ancilla single photon is injected into mode X via a single-photon emitter.  \n   3) At Charlie\u2019s station, modes C\u2081,C\u2082 and X are mixed in a Pytheus-designed linear-optical network (the bound-state scissor), whose click pattern on two herald detectors H\u2081,H\u2082 enacts the non-unitary map  \n        M_g \u221d g\u00b7P_sym  (P_sym projects onto Span{|01\u27e9+|10\u27e9})  \n      thereby **amplifying** the bound-state amplitude by gain g>1 and discarding the orthogonal subspace.  \n   4) Conditioned on an H\u2081\u2013H\u2082 click, the two amplified ancilla modes then enter a second Pytheus-designed Bell analyzer with one half of an SPDC pair on modes (B,C\u2083). A click on its herald detectors swaps the purified, amplified bound-state qubit onto Bob\u2019s mode B.  \n   5) We compare teleportation fidelity and overall heralding probability (\u201cabsorption\u201d) against a reference network without the scissor. The symmetry-protected scissor yields **higher** post-selection rates for the same fidelity, directly linking bound-state protection to enhanced light absorption in a quantum network transformation.\n\nVisualization:\n  Emitters: [ SPDC\u2081\u2192(A\u2081,C\u2081)  |  SPDC\u2082\u2192(A\u2082,C\u2082)  |  single-photon\u2192X ]  \n  Module 1 (bound scissor): [ C\u2081,C\u2082,X \u2192 Pytheus network \u2192 H\u2081,H\u2082 ]  \n  Module 2 (Bell swap): [ one amplified ancilla mode + half of SPDC\u2083\u2192(B,C\u2083) \u2192 Pytheus network \u2192 H\u2083,H\u2084 ]  \n  Output: Bob\u2019s mode B holds the teleported bound-state qubit.\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description:   \"Teleportation of a bound-state qubit with pre-amplification via a symmetry-protected quantum scissor\",\n  foldername:    \"BoundScissorTeleport\",\n  bulk_thr:      0.01,\n  edges_tried:   30,\n  ftol:          1e-06,\n  loss_func:     \"cr_abs\",      # maximize herald probability given fidelity\n  num_anc:       4,             # H\u2081,H\u2082 for scissor + H\u2083,H\u2084 for swap\n  optimizer:     \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples:       20,\n  single_emitters: [ X ],       # ancilla photon on mode X\n  pair_sources:  [[A\u2081,C\u2081],[A\u2082,C\u2082],[B,C\u2083]],\n  target_map:    \"M_g on symmetric subspace then Bell swap\", \n  removed_connections: [[X,A\u2080],[X,B]],  # prevent emitter from leaking to I/O modes\n  number_resolving: True,\n  anc_detectors: [H\u2081,H\u2082,H\u2083,H\u2084]\n}\n\nGeneralizations:\n \u2022 Replace the two-mode bound qubit by a three-mode bound qutrit and design a scissor for the three-photon symmetric subspace.  \n \u2022 Chain multiple scissor-swap modules into a repeater with cumulative absorption enhancement.  \n \u2022 Vary the gain g to study the trade-off between amplification, fidelity and heralding in a symmetry-protected channel.\n\nThis target goes beyond state generation\u2014it's a new non-unitary network primitive (the bound-state scissor) embedded in a teleportation protocol. It directly tests how symmetry protection can enhance coupling (heralding) in a quantum network transformation, all within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical, post-selected toolbox."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target measurement-induced photonic quantum SWITCH of two entanglement-breaking dephasing channels using ancilla photons, passive linear optics, and post-selection to emulate a discrete cross-Kerr coupling between a control and two data paths. Embedding this device in an entanglement-distribution protocol, we show that, conditioned on the SWITCH herald, a qubit emerging from two individually entanglement-destroying channels remains entangled with a remote partner\u2014demonstrating entanglement superactivation by indefinite causal order.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Hybrid-Frequency Triangle-Network Nonlocality Test with Photonic-Resonator Joint Measurements\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a self-contained three-party triangle nonlocality experiment in which two optical and one THz probabilistic Bell-pair sources feed three nodes arranged in a loop, with node B employing a small photonic-resonator interferometer to mix optical and THz modes for heralded two-outcome joint measurements. Encoded entirely in the Pytheus framework using beam splitters, phase shifters and number-resolving detectors, the scheme allows optimization of local measurement phases to maximize violation of Fritz\u2019s triangle network Bell inequality in a mixed-frequency architecture.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: PT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\n\nAbstract: We implement entanglement swapping on two polarization-encoded Bell pairs using a central PT-symmetric, non-unitary Bell-state analyser. By heralding the projector onto the PT-modified Bell state (the target map) and tuning its gain/loss parameter \u03b3, the protocol controllably generates a two-photon output |\u03a8_AD\u27e9\u221d|HH\u27e9+\u03b3\u2009e^{i\u03d5}|VV\u27e9 with adjustable, non-maximal entanglement.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic SWAP-Test Network for Direct Measurement of Quadratic Fermion Entanglement Spectrum\n\nAbstract: We propose a static linear-optical network whose target transformation is the global SWAP operator enacted across two N-mode photonic registers encoding identical copies of a quadratic fermionic ground state, realized via parallel Bell-pair ancillas and entanglement-swapping modules. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe demonstrate a heralded, non-unitary PT-symmetric gain\u2013loss filter embedded in the Bell-state measurement of a teleportation-based CNOT between photonic qubit A (control) and qubit C (target). By using SPDC-pair ancillas, four-port interferometric mixing, and number-resolving detection to preferentially amplify even-parity Bell components, our scheme surpasses the 50% passive-linear-optics limit and boosts both the success probability and fidelity of the nonlocal CNOT gate.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Experiment Title: Symmetry-Protected Bound\u2010State Qubit Teleportation with Enhanced Heralding\n\nDescription:\nWe encode a logical qubit into two photonic modes at Alice and Bob by restricting to the symmetric two\u2010photon subspace (\u201cbound state\u201d protected by mode\u2010exchange symmetry), which enhances the coupling (absorption) into detectors. We then teleport this bound\u2010state\u2013encoded qubit from Alice to Bob via a central node Charlie using entanglement swapping. By comparing the heralding statistics to a standard teleporter, we directly observe \u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d due to the symmetry\u2010protected bound\u2010state encoding. The network can be generalized to longer chains or higher\u2010dimensional bound\u2010state encodings.\n\nVisualization:\n\u2022 Alice\u2019s logical qubit: two modes A\u2081, A\u2082, with unknown state \u2223\u03c8\u27e9 in the symmetric subspace Span{\u222301\u27e9+\u222310\u27e9, \u222300\u27e9, \u222311\u27e9\u2026 restricted to two\u2010dim logical basis}.  \n\u2022 Two SPDC sources produce Bell\u2010pairs: one between modes B\u2081\u2013C\u2081, one between modes B\u2082\u2013C\u2082. Modes C\u2081,C\u2082 are sent to Charlie; modes B\u2081,B\u2082 go to Bob.  \n\u2022 At Alice: her bound\u2010state qubit in A\u2081,A\u2082 plus the two\u2010mode halves of an entangled resource with Charlie (another SPDC) feed into a linear\u2010optical network.  \n\u2022 Charlie performs a joint, symmetry\u2010respecting four\u2013mode Bell measurement on A\u2081,A\u2082,C\u2081,C\u2082 (heralding detectors).  \n\u2022 Upon a specific click pattern, the bound\u2010state qubit is teleported to Bob\u2019s modes B\u2081,B\u2082, still within the symmetric subspace.  \n\u2022 We record both teleportation fidelity and heralding rate\u2014enhanced absorption manifests as higher post\u2010selected rates for bound\u2010state encoding vs. standard dual\u2010rail encoding.\n\nKey Pytheus Config Elements (to be found by Expert):\n\u2022 num_anc = detectors at Charlie  \n\u2022 single_emitters or pair_sources for each SPDC link  \n\u2022 removed_connections to forbid direct ties from Alice to Bob  \n\u2022 target_quantum = logical mapping {\u2223bound0\u27e9\u2192\u2223bound0\u27e9, \u2223bound1\u27e9\u2192\u2223bound1\u27e9}  \n\u2022 loss_func = maximize heralding probability subject to teleportation fidelity\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Use qutrit bound\u2010state encoding (three\u2010mode symmetric subspace) for three\u2010level logic  \n\u2022 Chain multiple teleporter nodes to build a repeater network with symmetry\u2010protected links  \n\u2022 Swap standard swapping nodes for bound\u2010state superdense\u2010coding modules to transmit more information per herald click\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While teleporting a two-photon \u201cbound\u2010state\u201d logical qubit via swapping and comparing heralding rates is an interesting twist on dual\u2010rail teleportation, it does not introduce a genuinely new measurement\u2010induced transformation or network primitive beyond existing entanglement\u2010swapping/teleportation variants. Encoding in the symmetric two\u2010photon subspace is essentially a straightforward extension of multi\u2010mode teleportation, and the claimed \u201cenhanced absorption\u201d lacks a clear mechanism that distinguishes it from simply having two photons available for heralding. This remains an incremental performance comparison rather than a fundamentally novel target (e.g., no new nontrivial bound\u2010state physics or topological protection is demonstrated).  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The proposal must go beyond re\u2010encoding a qubit in two photons and running a standard swap\u2010based teleporter. To be PRL\u2010worthy, you would need to identify a truly new bound\u2010state phenomenon\u2014such as a nonperturbative photon\u2010photon bound state in a nonlinear waveguide or a symmetry\u2010protected topological bound mode\u2014and show how teleportation or network operations uniquely probe that physics. Provide a clear, nontrivial effect that has not been captured by existing teleportation or entanglement\u2010swapping experiments.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Experiment Title: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Qubit Teleportation\n\nexplanation:\n  We encode a logical qubit into two photonic modes (Alice\u2019s modes A\u2080,A\u2081) by restricting to their symmetric subspace (\u201cbound state,\u201d protected by mode-exchange symmetry). A standard Bell-pair source creates an entangled resource between Charlie\u2019s modes C\u2080,C\u2081 and Bob\u2019s modes B\u2080,B\u2081. Alice and Charlie perform a joint four-mode Bell measurement that respects the same symmetry, heralding teleportation of the bound-state qubit from A\u2080,A\u2081 to B\u2080,B\u2081. By comparing the heralding probability and teleportation fidelity of this bound-state scheme to a reference dual-rail teleportation, one directly observes \u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d (higher post-selection rates) due to the symmetry-protected bound state. Alice holds mode 0, Bob holds mode 3. At Charlie\u2019s node, modes 1 and 2 are fed into a C\u2083-symmetric three-port linear-optical interferometer whose design is optimized by Pytheus. This interferometer has one special two-photon eigenmode\u2014a \u201cbound state\u201d\u2014protected by its three-fold rotational symmetry. When the incoming photons from modes 1 and 2 occupy that bound subspace, interference directs them with anomalously high probability into two heralding detectors. A click pattern on Charlie\u2019s detectors simultaneously (a) entangles modes 0 and 3 (entanglement swap) and (b) exhibits an enhanced heralding probability (\u201cenhanced light absorption\u201d) versus a conventional two-port Bell-analyzer. By comparing both swap-fidelity and heralding rates against a reference linear-optical swap, one directly measures the absorption enhancement due to the symmetry-protected bound state. This bound-state swap module naturally generalizes to chains of nodes for repeaters or to higher-mode cyclic symmetries (C\u2084, C\u2085, \u2026).\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Entanglement swap via a symmetry\u2010protected C\u2083 bound\u2010state filter\",\n  foldername: \"BoundStateSwap_C3\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,                         # two herald detectors at Charlie\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: False,\n  safe_hist: True,\n  samples: 15,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],        # post\u2010selected Bell on modes 0 and 3\n  in_nodes: [],\n  out_nodes: [0,3],\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  heralding_out: [1,2],               # Charlie\u2019s detectors\n  single_emitters: [],                # two SPDC pair sources only\n  removed_connections: [],            # sources only link (0,1) and (2,3)\n  number_resolving: True,\n  anc_detectors: [1,2],\n}\n\nThis network leverages Pytheus\u2019s ability to find the optimal linear-optical three-port implementing the non-trivial bound\u2010state projector, inserted as the swap measurement.
